newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel-Credibility, not decimal points, key to EMU.
newsitem.headline: Waigel-Credibility, not decimal points, key to EMU.

text.p: German finance minister Theo Waigel said on Thursday he was not keen to engage in a debate over the decimal points in the Maastricht criteria for Euroepan economic and monetary union.

"I will not engage in a discussion about decimal points. It is a question of credibility," Waigel told German television. "If Germany were to discuss figures like 3.3 or 3.2 percent, others would start to talk about 3.8 percent."
Waigel was referring to the EMU entry criterion calling on member states to reduce budget deficits to at most three percent of gross domestic product (GDP)in 1997.
The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development released a report earlier on Thursday that forecast Germany's deficit would be 3.2 percent of GDP this year.
But Waigel, who has come in for sharp criticism in recent weeks for failing to present credible plans to ensure Germany meets EMU entry rules, said Germany would beat the OECD forecast.
"We will do better than 3.2 percent," he said.
